ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much Hebrew! I entered the class barely knowing any Hebrew except the alphabet, and slowly but surely I already feel like I speak a lot of Hebrew. Through the format of the class, you become really comfortable conversing in Hebrew as well as reading, writing and listening. I also gained new insights into Israeli culture and how Modern Hebrew has evolved.
Basic conversational Hebrew, plus how to start studying a language for the very first time in a group setting
Hebrew alphabet, counting, reading, writing, listening, verbs in the present tense.
I learned to read, write, speak, and listen in Hebrew quite a fair amount in such a short amount of time.
I learned how to communicate in the present tense, how to read both block and script Hebrew, practiced listening, and explored the cultural context of Hebrew.
I learned a lot about the basics of Hebrew. I went from only knowing the alphabet to being able to hold a very basic conversation.
Introduction to the Hebrew language with a focus on new vocab and grammar.

! (Show, don't tell!)
I wouldn't, in a million years, have been able to reach such a level of proficiency in Hebrew  in such a short time without Dina's amazing guidance in this class. Take it, and you'll in no time be able to read, write, listen and speak in Hebrew!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Fosters a really nice community within the program. Cultural events. Carefully thought-out vocabulary for each week with creative assignments.
Weaknesses: It's a lot of homework (but manageable) every night, but it's definitely worth it in the end.
Very well organized and all the material both fits together and is broken into manageable pieces. I even wished there'd been a little more weekly vocab.
This course was fabulous and truly a lot of fun if you are willing to put in the time and effort.
No weaknesses. Loved it. Super fun.
I loved Padlet.  Everything was very organized and it was easy to see what we had to do for the entire week.

This course is an excellent foundation for anybody looking to get started with Hebrew. Its main flaw is that many of the students already have a background in the language. True newcomers can feel lost and sometimes left behind in class material due to their peers demonstrating a much more solid grasp of the language.

Padlet was a great tool, that was definitely a strength, although I think too many assignments/texts were assigned daily sometimes and it became overwhelming. Weekly vocab lists were a great tool and helped organize learning for each week and what we were being held responsible for. Material built on itself well. The course did ramp up quite a bit at the end with a new binyan every week, and I think the "et" accusative should be taught a bit earlier in the semester; it's not super hard to understand and I think we could have benefited from being able to solidify it more into our knowledge and speaking by learning it maybe before the roots/binyanim. I also liked doing some assignments as a class so that we can hear real time corrections, but doing them again at home if they were homework should be optional. I do wish this course touched on past tense since that's the one thing missing that really makes you conversational, just in case you want to get that full foundation from only L1 and not L2 (where it's taught).

Strengths: Very very organized professor, coupled with the excellent Padlet interface! Predictable course-load, weekly assignment, and class material. It's a 1.5 credit so there's certainly work to keep you occupied, but very adaptable to your semester if you easily set aside time to work on the daily/weekly assignments (Vocab memorization, Google Doc assignments, etc.).

Weakness: Could be a lil' too draining at some point in the semester to go to class EVERY 10:30AM morning of your week. Honestly, it may be possible to make one of the days asynchronous/just on Zoom. Maybe.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! If you're interested in learning Hebrew, this is the course to take. You will learn more than you ever thought possible. I'm very grateful I took this class. But make sure you have the time and passion for the language before taking this class.
Yes. It's not something that you can slack on for any length of time during the semester except perhaps the weekends, but the materials are well-organized, the teaching is clear and class is fun.

Yes, if you are interested in learning the language then yes. I think Hebrew is probably pretty tough for a lot of people coming in with zero background, but definitely manageable if you are willing to put in the time and effort. If you are looking for an easy language to fulfill the distribution, go take Indonesian or something else. This class is great for those interested in learning Hebrew and some Israeli culture.

Yes, if you have any interest in learning Hebrew, take this class. The structure of the course is well planned out and you learn Hebrew quickly. Even if you haven't thought about Hebrew before, it's a beautiful language. I highly recommend.

I would definitely recommend this course to other people. Its so cool to be able to speak another language. The amount I learned in this class is incredible. It was however a lot of work, but it was worth it in my opinion.

Anybody interested in the Hebrew language should take this course. I would only recommend taking it if you are prepared to have a lot of homework every day. I would not recommend taking this course alongside other demanding courses such as DS or CS50.

YES! This was the best language course I've taken at Yale (having been through many of the departments) as far as structure and ability to teach you the language. Dina's pedagogy is amazing and I wouldn't miss an opportunity to take L1 with her. Also going to class was honestly a fun and positive experience every day, while in other departments usually at least a couple days a week feel like a drag just because it's a daily class. The class has great community and I think Jewish or non-Jewish alike, students bonded with their classmates and really engaged with the material. I also am realizing by engaging in Hebrew language media outside of the class that she really taught us everything you need to have a solid foundation in conversational Hebrew, including cultural aspects and highly common expressions like "baruch haShem" and "ma pitom". We didn't even learn the colors in L1, which is kind of strange, but it's clear in retrospect that the vocab and verbs we learned were exactly what was logical and necessary.

100%. Remotely interested in learning the Hebrew language. Jump right in   ("my friend")! Your friend over here had zero experience with Hebrew before this class, but can now think in Hebrew not just talk. With not much bloodsweat.
